profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid was generated by The Texas Collection staff, using the STAR Knowledge Center for Archives (SKCA) task that automatically creates EAD files from the Archive's SKCA catalog records.

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: This collection consists of four scripts and screenplays written by Rose Franken. Franken was a novelist and playwright best known for her "Claudia" stories and for their stage and film adaptations.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Born in 1895, Rose Franken spent her early life in Gainesville, Texas. At the age of twelve, however, Franken’s parents separated and she moved with her mother and siblings to New York City. There she completed her education, married, and began writing novels while raising her three children. Franken produced from these novels a number of successful theater productions and motion pictures, including several which depicted the well-known character of Claudia Naughton, a young housewife. Franken’s writings frequently used simple domestic situations to offer broad social commentary. Franken remained an active writer into the 1960s, and died in Arizona in 1988.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of one series, I. Literary Productions, consisting of two synopses and two screenplays written by Rose Franken between 1936 and 1946.

The first screenplay, Hurdy-Gurdy (1936), is a mid-nineteenth-century romance set in New York City. While Hurdy-Gurdy was never produced as a film, this collection's other three items were used in the production of two motion pictures featuring Franken’s “Claudia” character. Claudia (1941) and Another Claudia (1942), two brief synopses of Franken’s earlier stories, were used in the development of the 1943 film Claudia. Additionally, a "final shooting" screenplay titled Claudia and David was used in the production of a 1946 sequel by the same name. Both “Claudia” films starred Dorothy McGuire--better known for her later roles in Gentleman’s Agreement (1947), The Swiss Family Robinson (1960), and The Greatest Story Ever Told (1965)--and depicted the marital challenges of the title character. This collection is in good condition.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prior to current processing, each screenplay was wrapped in plastic. Each item has now been foldered and the collection now has one series, I. Literary Productions.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to The Texas Collection in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Rose Franken Screenplay collection, Accession #3967, Box #, Folder #, The Texas Collection, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Ben Leavitt. Released on 2017-07-18.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains two screenplays and two synopses written by Rose Franken. The series is in good condition.
